comments.author: Jeremy Wagner
comments.message: Excellent article on WebP. I've also had much of the same success with it that you'd had here, and would heartily recommend it to anyone.

comments.author: George Liu
comments.message: You can definite reduce image size with webp and nginx can be configured to conditionally serve webp to supported browsers https://centminmod.com/webp/. I did webp benchmarks at https://github.com/centminm... as well :)

comments.author: Eric Portis
comments.message: It is fun and cool see exactly how and why you’re experimenting with this stuff. Why `cwebp -q 80`? Any subjective thoughts on how the ImageOptim PNG/Jpeg/WebP quality compares?

replies.author: zachleat
replies.message:
Heh, that choice was arbitrary, for sure.

Good questions! I’d like to look at the quality comparisons more—do you know of a good tool to do image diffs that works with WebP?

comments.author: Kornel
comments.message:
Have you tried using MozJPEG with "compressive images" preset? (Described here: https://calendar.perfplanet... )

Even according to Google's own test WebP is only up to 30% smaller than JPEG, so if you're seeing a difference bigger than that, it's a warning sign. You should be able to get to similar file size range with well compressed JPEGs. Try re-saving them, or try the "high-DPI" setting here:

https://imageoptim.com/mozjpeg

comments.author: Luke Cavanagh
comments.message: If only WebP was supported by Firefox and Edge.

comments.author: Christoph
comments.message:
Can you help me with the batch script please?

I put in into file and tried to run it via 'sh script' but I get an error: script: 4: script: Syntax error: "(" unexpected

replies.author: zachleat
replies.message: I put it into my .zshrc file but you may use a .bash_profile or something else to hold all of your reusable shell scripts. You can go down the dotfiles rabbit hole to see examples of how other people do it: https://dotfiles.github.io/
